DOC.HEADLINE: THE PLANET, A WEB-HOSTING COMPANY, FINDS ITS OWN ORBIT

TEXT.P: HOUSTON -- Three years ago, investors bought two stagnant Web-hosting companies and merged them into what is now known as The Planet.
They tasked newly appointed CEO Doug Erwin with melding two different corporate cultures, turning profits and taking the company public. Observers say he's done well by hitting two out of three.
"IPOs are not a possibility at the moment" for anyone, said Dan Golding, vice president of Tier 1 Research, "so that's not a negative for them, necessarily."
"The real value is that they took two firms that had really sort of plateaued and put them together successfully. That's a very difficult trick to do."

The privately held company won't disclose net income figures but said its annual revenue runs about $150 million. When the two companies merged, they had combined revenues of less than $100 million, officials said.
The merger

GI Partners, a California-based private equity firm, bought Houston's EV1 Servers whose sister dial-up business Everyones Internet was sold off and Dallas-based The Planet separately. It joined the two in 2006, eventually making Houston the company's headquarters.
News of the merger between EV1 and The Planet wasn't greeted by each company's employees with much enthusiasm.
They were also dealing with new top management, including Erwin.
Employees in each city considered their business practices better, Erwin said. So he had employees from Dallas and Houston meet at a gymnasium in Crockett for a competition.

He gave each employee 10 toy bricks and told them to build something. Whoever built the most creative sculpture would get to pick where the piece would sit in the company's new downtown Houston offices.

After discovering they couldn't build much with 10 bricks each, the employees formed teams to build a construction zone, a server, a pyramid and other sculptures, all of which are on display at the headquarters in Bayou Place.
"I told them we were rebuilding the company brick by brick," Erwin said. Some from Dallas ended up winning, "so every time the Houston folks walk in, they have to look at it."
New markets
Aside from getting employees to get along, the new management also had to make the company profitable and expand it.
First, they used the combined company's buying power to renegotiate contracts with everyone from the utility company to Dell, which provides all of The Planet's servers.
The company cut costs enough to turn a profit within a year of the merger.

Last year it also moved from solely renting servers used to host Web sites and run applications to managing the servers for businesses, competing with companies like San Antonio-based Rackspace Hosting.

Late last year, The Planet entered the cloud storage space storage accessed from anywhere via the Web and started renewed efforts to push its co-location services, which is essentially renting space in data centers for companies that want to locate servers off site.
Today, 50 percent of the company's revenue comes from services neither company offered before the merger.
"We've achieved our growth," finance chief Kevin Klausmeyer said. He added that the company is targeting small to medium-size businesses. Almost half of its customers are overseas.
Growth has slowed since September as the economy declined, he said, but the company still managed to secure a $45 million credit line in October that it has never used.

But sustaining growth while introducing new products could prove challenging, Golding said. Last year, for instance, an outage caused by a fire at one of its Houston data centers knocked the sites of about 8,000 customers offline. The company waived monthly fees for its customers for two months and is trying to recover the lost income, more than $3 million, from its insurance company.

"When you're growing at the pace they're growing, you're going to run into problems you're never going to see," Golding said. "Your customers expect you to execute perfectly. They also need to introduce new products and hit the cloud computing wave. Doing all that at the pace they're growing is tough."
Going public?
Whether the company eventually goes public doesn't matter, Erwin said. He's running the company as if it were, he added.
Erwin ran Houston-based blade server company RLX Technologies with Klausmeyer before Hewlett-Packard Co. bought it in 2005.
"Whether we go public or not, time will tell," said Erwin. "But that's how you add value. I've done this four times before, and we never made it to the altar. It always got sold."
